Award.AwardTitle: ECR: BCSER: Conference: Integrating STEM Education Research Collaboration for Regional Prosperity
Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed three-day conference "Integrating STEM Education Research Collaboration for Regional Prosperity" will highlight topics relevant to STEM education and workforce development in the greater Kansas City region. STEM education topics will include supporting student success, broadening participation in STEM, and developing partnerships between two- and four-year institutions. Regional prosperity topics will include identifying high-impact practices to retain STEM majors, promoting STEM careers, and building coalitions among regional stakeholders. Participants will present research and learn from each other while working together to identify how post-secondary education can improve its commitment to STEM student success and regional prosperity. The conference will support local and national efforts that increase STEM degree attainment, diversify the STEM workforce, and expand interdisciplinary approaches to post-secondary STEM education. <br/><br/>The conference has four goals: 1) Support STEM education researchers to identify critical challenges, opportunities, and actionable solutions to retain STEM-aspirational students and graduate a diverse workforce; 2) Engage best practices on the frontiers of collective impact, institutional transformation, and data-informed collaboration; 3) Apply new knowledge and innovations to projects addressing both institutional and societal needs; and 4) Provide a venue for research dissemination and collaborative problem-solving. The conference will convene a "Think Tankâ€ (conference plus networked improvement community) of top researchers, practitioners, and professionals who will collaboratively design, collect, and analyze data. Results of this analysis will support STEM education improvements to prepare a diverse STEM workforce that will promote increased regional prosperity. Ultimately, the conference outcomes will contribute an actionable set of data that can be useful for demystifying factors related to post-secondary attrition in the region and identifying feasible educational technology and pedagogies to improve STEM student retention. Additionally, the conference will develop a general ecosystem model focused on the unique academic, social, and cultural factors influencing STEM education research. The project is supported through the EHR Core Research: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research (ECR: BCSER) competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Integrating STEM Education Research Collaboration for Regional Prosperity

PIs: Alexis Petri, Chris Liu, and Tiffani Riggers-Piehl
University of Missouri-Kansas City 

 

OUTCOMES Report

Summary of the Project

As a conference grant, Integrating STEM Education Research Collaboration for Regional Prosperity (known publicly as: Integrating STEM +KC), provided multiple opportunities for training and professional development focused on how postsecondary education can improve its commitment to STEM student success and regional prosperity. Due to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, we translated the conference to a series of synchronous workshops connected by networked improvement communities (NICs).
The Integrating STEM+KC conference convened five times over the life of the grant. Each convening hosted speakers in the deconstructed conference meetings that addressed issues related to the educational experience for constituents within STEM fields and the KC region. Speakers addressed the need for improved mentoring and research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, issues of historic racial oppression within educational institutions and approaches university stakeholders can take to remake the institution into a more equitable and just space, the power of cross-collaborative networks for improved educational success, and ways to use data to improve educational experiences. Emphasis was placed on developing relationships between community organizations, two-year institutions, and four-year institutions. The conference led to enhanced teaching and learning experiences for college students and stronger networks among faculty and community leaders. 

The Integrating STEM + KC conference had a goal of examining the academic, social, and cultural factors that influence STEM in the KC region. The conference did that by creating new teams of stakeholders to examine the challenges to STEM workforce development in the region and putting innovation at the forefront of the way we examine the challenges rather than staying in disciplinary and sector silos. Additionally, the presence of community organizations who focus on collecting workforce data to improve economic equity allowed educational leaders to improve their awareness of data available to them and to apply it to their work in a more sophisticated manner. These improvements in the partnerships between education and community organizations focused on equitable gains for all of the Kansas City metro area and the stakeholders who value education and PK-20 growth in the greater KC region. 

 Additionally, Integrating STEM + KC was designed to provide cross-sector teams essential support for initiating a collective ecosystem approach to impact STEM education and workforce issues in the Kansas City metro region. The core work of ecosystem impact for Integrating STEM + KC was carried out by NICs that brought scholars and professionals together to engage in learning and collaboration for change. Integrating STEM + KC supported three separate NICs. Associated NICs brought together faculty from different institutions (2yr and 4yr), students, and community partners to address: urban pre-STEM programs, supporting community colleges on their journey into the technology workforce, and increasing diverse student interest in STEM degrees through undergraduate research.

Products of the Project

Networked Improvement Community (NICs) Summaries

As noted above, three NICs were established to develop multiperspective approaches to identifying STEM workforce challenges. The three NICs established in the Integrating STEM + KC conference framework were each led by a faculty or staff member at UMKC (described as "champions" in the conference framework); though leadership by a UMKC community member was not a requirement. Each NIC was required to include at least one member from a community organization, one from a community college context, at least one student (undergraduate or graduate), and someone from a four-year college context. Many NICs had multiple people from each of these contexts. Information about the NICs are available below: 

 

  • NIC1: Urban Pre-STEM Programs to Increase Underrepresented STEM Graduates | This NIC focused on identifying the lived experiences of successful STEM students from historically excluded groups the resources that helped them to be successful while in college.
  • NIC2: Pathways to Equitable and Accessible Careers in Computing and Engineering (PEACE): Guiding and Supporting Community College Students on their Journey into the Technology Workforce | This NIC worked together to improve transfer between 2yr and 4yr STEM programs. 
  • NIC3: Strengthening Pathways from High School to 4-yr STEM Degree Attainment: Broadening Student Success | Participants in this NIC focused on the ways that high school students choose STEM and how colleges and improve retention into and persistence through STEM degrees and into the STEM workforce.

STEM Student Stories Project and Mentoring Opportunities

Integrating STEM + KC also included a STEM Student Advisory Panel who shared their experiences as college/university students majoring in STEM at the undergraduate and graduate level. The Student Panelists joined with conference participants in the July meeting and also shared their stories via a video storytelling format. 

STEM Student Stories can be found on our conference website: https://sites.google.com/umsystem.edu/integrating-stem/stem-student-panel/stem-student-stories?authuser=0
